intro: Cracca madrensis, commonly known as the Madre de Cielo, is a flowering plant native to the Andean regions of South America. It belongs to the family Polygonaceae, which includes plants known for their distinctive leaf shapes and often vibrant flowers. The plant is characterized by its erect stems and clusters of small, bright yellow flowers that bloom in the spring. Its leaves are typically lance-shaped and covered in a dense layer of fine hairs. Cracca madrensis is often found in rocky or mountainous habitats, where it thrives in well-drained soils and full sun exposure.
